title: Book: Atomic Habits
author: Author: James Clear
story:
The Book That Changed Me

I remember the day I stumbled upon Atomic Habits by James Clear in a bookstore. I wasn’t looking for anything in particular, but that title pulled me in. Page after page, I realized how small actions build into massive change. That book didn’t just sit on my shelf — it helped me build consistency in everything I do, from studying to self-care. Sometimes, a single book finds you at the exact moment you need it.

title: Book: The Silent Patient
author: Author: Alex Michaelides
story:
From Zero to Reader

I was never a reader. Books felt long, boring, and too slow for my fast-paced mind. But during one long summer break, I challenged myself to read just 10 pages a day. I started with The Silent Patient, a mystery novel that hooked me from the first chapter. Then came another book, then non-fiction. Now, books are my comfort zone. It’s funny how 10 pages a day turned into a lifelong habit.

title: Book: The Alchemist
author: Author: Paulo Coelho
story:
The Night I Read Instead of Scrolling

It was 2 AM, and I was about to scroll mindlessly through social media. But I paused and opened The Alchemist instead. That night, I got lost in Santiago's journey to follow his dreams. It made me think about my own goals, the signs around me, and the courage it takes to believe in yourself. That book became my late-night friend — and an eye-opener.

title: Book: Man’s Search for Meaning
author: Author: Viktor E. Frankl
story:
The Power of Re-Reading

There’s this one book I re-read every year — Man’s Search for Meaning by Viktor Frankl. Each time, it hits differently. The first time, it helped me get through heartbreak. The next, through a tough academic year. And the last time, it helped me find peace in chaos. Some books are like mirrors — they reflect different parts of you depending on where you are in life.

title: Book: Tuesdays with Morrie
author: Author: Mitch Albom
story:
Reading to Heal

When I lost someone close, I couldn’t talk to anyone. I didn’t know how. Then I read Tuesdays with Morrie by Mitch Albom. It felt like Morrie was talking directly to me, guiding me, comforting me. Reading didn’t solve everything — but it reminded me I wasn’t alone in my pain. Stories can be soft places to fall.
